I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  Fiji  has  requested  technical  assistance  (TA)  from  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to support the development of institutional capacity for regulation of 
Fiji’s electricity sector, and for development of a sector investment planning framework.  ADB 
consulted with government representatives in March 2015 and agreed on the impact, outcome, 
outputs, implementation, cost, financing, and terms of reference of the TA. The design and 
monitoring framework for the TA is in Appendix 1.1  The proposed TA is included in the country 
operations business plan, 2015–2017. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Fiji’s  power  sector  is  dominated  by  the  Fiji  Electricity  Authority  (FEA),  a  statutory 
authority  established  under  the  provisions  of  the  Electricity  Act  of  1966.  FEA  officers  are 
appointed by the Minister for Energy and Mineral Resources. FEA is the sole entity authorized 
to generate, transmit, distribute, and sell electricity in Fiji, and to license other entities to operate 
in the power sector. 
 
3.  The Government of Fiji has indicated its intention to increase the share of private-sector 
participation in the power sector through corporatization and privatization of FEA, and through 
the attraction of new entrants on a competitive basis in key market segments (in particular 
generation). The government expects that this will yield efficiency increases within the sector 
through the forces of competition, and accelerate investment in new  assets to meet Fiji’s 
growing demand and increase the share of renewable sources in its generation mix. To facilitate 
these  processes  and  achieve  these  objectives,  developing  a  credible,  modern  and  robust 
regulatory regime for the power sector is essential. 
 
4.  Fiji’s installed capacity is about 263 megawatts, comprising 136 megawatts of renewable 
generation  (hydro,  wind,  solar,  and  biomass),  with  the  remainder  consisting  of  fossil  fuel 
plants—diesel  or  heavy  fuel  oil.  Total  power  generation  in  2013  was  approximately  62% 
renewable, 38% fossil fuel. Fiji’s newly revised sector policy set targets of 67% renewable 
generation by 2015, and 99% by 2030.2 To this end, FEA has been pursuing renewable energy 
investments,  the  latest  addition  being  the  40-megawatt  Nadarivatu  hydroelectric  plant 
commissioned  in  2012.  Favorable  rainfall  and  the  addition  of  Nadarivatu  allowed  FEA  to 
generate 65% of its output from hydroelectric sources in 2012 (a 15% increase in hydroelectric 
generation over 2011). Complemented by a 37% increase in wind power output, diesel and 
heavy fuel oil generation decreased to 42% of total output (21% below 2011). Nevertheless, 
FEA expenditure on diesel and heavy fuel oil totaled over F$105 million in 2012, roughly 48% of 
total costs.3 
 
5.  Most of Fiji’s power generation is owned by FEA. Two independent power producers 
contractually authorized to sell to FEA account for 2.4% of installed grid-connected capacity in 
Fiji (Tropik Wood Industries Limited and Fiji Sugar Corporation, both of which use biomass as 
fuel stock). FEA’s customer base consists largely of residential consumers (91%), commercial 
consumers (9%), and industrial consumers (<0.1%). Consumption and revenue statistics are 
strikingly different, with 48% of electricity sales revenue attributed to commercial consumers,

26% to industrial consumers, and the remaining 26% to domestic consumers. Fiji’s electricity 
penetration  rate  among  households  is  roughly  90%,  with  a  state  policy  target  of  100% 
penetration by 2020 (footnote 2). Approximately 10% of the population is still without access to 
electricity and Fiji is struggling to provide remote areas and isolated islands with access to 
electricity in a sustainable manner. Additional network infrastructure and generation is needed 
to  expand  service  to  these  populations.  Overall,  Fiji’s  electricity  system  needs  significant 
investment, estimated to be in the order of $760 million (F$1.5 billion) (footnote 2), over the next 
decade. 
 
6.   Despite progress in increasing the share of renewable resources in Fiji’s generation mix, 
a high reliance on imported fuels remains. Grid-based power supply has arguably the greatest 
potential  to  make  Fiji’s  energy  sector  more  efficient,  cost  effective,  and  environmentally 
sustainable. There are a number of undeveloped but promising hydro sites, and significant 
unexplored geothermal, solar, and wind resources that can reduce Fiji’s reliance on fossil fuel 
generation.  
 
7.   As the sole statutory authority authorized to operate in the power sector, FEA exists 
effectively as a self-regulating entity. Tariffs are approved by the Fiji Commerce Commission, 
but the manner in which prices are reviewed is not transparent and does not offer the long-term 
certainty and predictability that private investors would prefer. Tariffs are distorted, and contain 
cross subsidy by industrial and commercial customers (F$0.42/kilowatt-hour [kWh]) in favor of 
residential  customers  (F$0.33/kWh).  For  domestic  customers,  the first  block  of  75 kWh  is 
subsidized  at  roughly  50%;  for  commercial  and  industrial  customers,  a  reduced  rate  of 
F$0.40/kWh is applied to the first 14,999 kWh per month, rising to F$0.42 thereafter. 
 
8.   This TA reflects the government’s intentions for sector regulation. In March 2015, ADB’s 
Private Sector Development Initiative presented an analysis of options for the creation of a 
multisector  regulatory  agency  based  on  existing  regulatory  institutions.  The  government’s 
preference is to consolidate regulatory functions within a single agency, rather than create 
separate agencies for each regulated industry or network monopoly. The government has not 
yet identified which existing institution might be transformed into such an agency, or whether an 
entirely new agency will be created; nor has it defined what will be the prospective agency’s 
scope of authority.  
 
9.  This TA coincides with the government’s pursuit of partial divestment of FEA. The 
establishment  of  a  credible  regulatory  regime  for  the  electricity  sector  is  essential  for  the 
maximization of the transaction’s value, and the stimulation of sector development through 
mobilization  of  private  investment.  A  coherent  investment  planning  framework  is  likewise 
important  to  direct  investments  (public  and  private)  in  accordance  with  government  policy 
objectives. 
 
10.  Government policy objectives include the following:  
 
(i)  Affordable energy for all. Ensure that all Fijians have access to affordable and 
reliable modern energy services.  
(ii)  Sustainable energy supplies. Establish environmentally sound and sustainable 
systems for energy production, procurement, transportation, distribution, and end 
use.  
(iii)  Reduced import costs. Encourage the efficient use of energy and the use of 
indigenous energy sources to reduce the financial burden of energy imports on 
Fiji.

3
 
11.  To achieve the objectives, government priority actions include: (i) expand role of the 
private sector in grid electricity generation, including the partial privatization of FEA; (ii) promote 
an increase in the contribution of non-FEA renewable energy, in particular from small-scale 
systems; (iii) restructure regulatory arrangements to improve transparency and accountability 
and  remove  possible  conflicts  of  interest;  and  (iv)  achieve  a  renewable  energy  share  in 
electricity generation of 99% by 2030. 
 
12.   Technical regulatory functions currently held by FEA, including licensing and approvals, 
will be transferred to a new multisector regulator. Options for division of essential regulatory 
functions will be the subject of analysis to be provided under the proposed TA. 
 
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
13.  The TA responds to the Government of Fiji’s request for ADB assistance to develop 
regulatory capacity and sector planning capacity within appropriate agencies. ADB’s country 
partnership strategy, 2014–2018 for Fiji focuses on three interlinked priorities of (i) raising Fiji’s 
longer-term growth potential, (ii) building resilience and reducing vulnerability, and (iii) reducing 
poverty through more inclusive growth and better service delivery. This TA supports all three of 
these priorities by promoting greater, more sustainable, and secure energy supply to Fiji’s 
population and economy. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The impact of the TA will be a resource efficient, cost effective, and environmentally 
sustainable energy sector. The outcome of the TA will be improved framework for development 
of Fiji's energy sector. The TA will improve the environment for private and public investment in 
Fiji’s energy sector and promote the expansion of renewable generation and electricity service 
to portions of Fiji’s population that currently do not enjoy formal electricity service. The TA will 
provide the foundation for a robust and best-practices energy sector regulatory environment as 
it relates to key aspects of economic regulation of public utilities and to sector development 
planning and investment.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The proposed TA has two distinct outputs: 
 
(i)  Output 1: Capacity development at selected regulatory agency. The TA will 
review existing legal and institutional frameworks governing the energy sector, and will 
produce  draft  legislation  to  assign  sector  regulation  responsibilities  to  designated 
government agencies. The identification of the government agency or agencies to which 
regulatory authorities and functions will be assigned will be the subject of examination 
under this component. The TA will also produce recommendations for the recipient 
regulatory agencies’ structures, resources, and personnel, to correspond with assigned 
regulatory responsibilities, and will provide training for selected personnel as described 
below; and 
  
(ii)  Output  2:  Enhanced  sector  planning  capacity  at  relevant  government 
department.    The  TA  will  work  with  the  selected  regulatory  agency  and  relevant 
government department to prepare sector planning and investment project screening

4  
methodologies,  and  will  produce  one  generation  and  one  network  investment  pre-
feasibility study under the proposed planning and project screening methodologies. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.1 million, of which $1.0 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources).  The Government of 
Fiji will provide counterpart support in the form of staff, office accommodation, and other in-kind 
contributions. The cost estimate and financing plan is in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA with the Pacific Department acting as the 
focal department. The Ministry of Finance will facilitate provision of all data and information from 
public and government sources necessary for consultants’ work and facilitate interaction with 
other government and nongovernment Fiji stakeholders. 
 
18.  For the first output, an international consultant will be engaged to analyze and confirm 
options for development of a multisector regulatory agency on the basis of existing government 
agencies  or  creation  of  a  new  agency;  assess  the  legal  framework  providing  for  sector 
regulation; draft enabling legislation or revisions to existing legislation; define the agency’s 
capacity development requirements; and develop recommendations for secondary legislation to 
enable the selected agency to begin to discharge its functions. The consultant will also identify 
required competencies and skills for the agency’s function and propose the training needed for 
personnel  to  perform  assigned  regulatory  functions,  prepare  criteria  for  the  selection  of 
personnel to receive training, assist in selecting candidates for training, and assist in identifying 
appropriate training opportunities to be funded under the TA. The international consultant will be 
supported by a national consultant with familiarity with the Fiji legislative process and norms of 
legislative drafting. Consultants will be hired on an individual consultant basis. Level of effort 
and contract period shall be 6 person-months (international) and 10 person-months (national) 
over 12 months (intermittent). 
  
19.  To support the first output, the TA will provide training for identified multisector regulatory 
agency and other government personnel in recognized professional training programs to be 
proposed by the consultant and confirmed by ADB. ADB will collaborate with consultants and 
the  executing  agency  to  identify  training  providers. Training  programs  will  be  off-the-shelf, 
resident short-term programs of approximately 2 weeks’ duration.4 
 
20.  For the second output, ADB will hire and manage a consulting firm to deliver detailed 
recommendations  for  establishing  the  underlying  policy  framework  for  the  identification, 
prioritization,  selection,  and  implementation  of  discrete  renewable  generation  and  service 
expansion  investments,  and  to  develop  sector  planning  capacity  and  project  screening 
methodologies within the regulatory agency and relevant government department, including the 
preparation of a geospatial inventory of existing power sector assets, infrastructures, renewable 
energy resources, and population centers of all permanently inhabited islands. The consulting 
firm will be hired under the quality- and cost-based selection method, with a ratio of 90:10 in 
favor of quality.

21.  Indicative  key  personnel  positions  for  the  second  output  include:  (i)  geographic 
information systems expert (2 person-months); legal and regulatory expert (3 person-months); 
renewable  energy  generation  expert(s)  (solar,  wind,  or  hydro,  to  be  confirmed;  4  person-
months); transmission and/or distribution electrical engineer (4 person-months); project finance 
expert  and  economist  (4  person  months);  private  sector  investment  and  public–private 
partnership advisor (4 person-months); environmental safeguards expert (2 person-months); 
and  social  and  poverty  expert  (2  person-months).    Contract  period  will  be  18  months 
(intermittent).5 
 
22.  Consultants  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  the  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). Disbursement will follow direct payment 
procedures in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). Outline terms of reference for consultants appear in Appendix 3. 
 
23.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months from approval to completion.  ADB will field 
an  inception  mission,  regular  review  missions,  a  midterm  review  mission,  and  finalization 
mission.  ADB will liaise closely with government counterparts and attend meetings between 
consultants  and  counterparts,  including  presentation  of  results  and  outputs.  ADB  and  the 
Ministry of Finance will closely monitor progress against schedules agreed at inception, and will 
evaluate consultants’ fulfilment of agreed terms of reference and deliverables requirements. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
24.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
 
the Government of Fiji for Support for Energy Sector Regulatory Capacity and Electrification 
Investment Planning, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

  experts to support proposed approach to implementation and achievement of project objectives.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.   Objectives and Scope 
 
1.  The  technical  assistance  will  be  administered  by  the  Pacific  Department  of  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB).  For the first output, an international public utilities regulatory expert 
will be contracted on an individual consultant basis, supported by a national legal expert. The 
TA  will  include  training  of  government  personnel  using  established  off-the-shelf  training 
programs (ADB will support consultants in identifying training options). The second output 
requires expertise in the following areas: geographic information systems; public utility legal and 
regulatory  practices;  solar,  wind,  and/or  hydroelectric  generation;  transmission  and/or 
distribution  electrical  engineering;  project  finance  and  economic  analysis;  private  sector 
investment and transaction preparation; and environmental and social safeguards compliance 
and monitoring. 
 
B.  Consulting Services to be Provided under this Technical Assistance 
 
2.  Output 1: Development of regulatory capacity at selected regulatory agency. The 
key objective will be the creation of electricity sector regulatory capacity at selected Government 
of Fiji institutions. Consultants will produce analyses of the current institutional capacity of 
candidate regulatory institutions; review existing legislation and draft new legislation to effect the 
transfer of regulatory functions to selected institutions, and to enhance regulatory powers and 
authorities;  and  prepare  a  program  of  institutional  and  personnel  capacity  development 
investment.  The following consultant positions are envisaged for this component:  
 
3.  Public  utilities  regulatory  expert(s)  (international  individual  consultant,  6  person- 
months, intermittent). The public utilities regulatory expert(s) will have an advanced degree in 
public  policy,  law,  economics,  or  related  field;  substantial  experience  in  institutional 
development  and  management  of  autonomous  or  independent  public  utility  regulatory 
authorities (with power sector oversight authority), either in a senior management position within 
such an institution or as a consultant to such institutions in their nascent stages; and experience 
and expertise in development of primary and/or enabling legislation for public utilities regulation. 
Tasks will include: 
(i)  analyze and confirm options for assignment of regulatory functions to candidate 
existing government agency or creation of new agency; 
(ii)  review of existing and evolving legal framework for energy sector (electricity) 
regulation in Fiji as it relates to regulatory mandate of a multisector regulator; 
(iii)  draft proposed legislation for multisector regulator, including development of the 
multisector regulator’s core “charter” (or equivalent); 
(iv)  perform a gap analysis of the selected multisector regulator’s capacity to execute 
regulatory mandate; 
(v)  develop recommendations for material resource requirements (i.e., assets and 
annual budget); 
(vi)  propose appropriate organizational structure and hierarchy, personnel structure, 
staff profiles, competence matrixes, and training requirements; 
(vii)  propose  roster  of  multisector  regulator  and  other  government  personnel  for 
training  in  recognized  international  training  programs  for  utilities  regulation 
practitioners; and 
(viii)  support selection of national consultant legal expert.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
4.   Legal expert (national consultant, 12 person-months, intermittent.) The legal expert will 
possess a formal legal qualification (juris doctorate or equivalent) and at least 10 years of 
professional experience in the legal profession. The legal expert will also have substantial 
legislative drafting experience in Fiji and familiarity with the legislative process in Fiji.  The legal 
expert will ensure that recommendations prepared by the public utilities regulatory expert are 
compatible with Fiji’s legal traditions and practices. The legal expert will support the public 
utilities regulatory expert in all of his tasks, including: 
(i)  research Fiji’s current relevant legal framework and institutional arrangements; 
(ii)  liaise  with  government  stakeholders  on  findings  and  recommendations  for 
transfer of regulator functions and establishment of multisector regulator; 
(iii)  draft necessary legislation for the creation of multisector regulator and transfer of 
regulatory functions from the Fiji Electricity Authority (FEA); and 
(iv)  draft  institutional  charter  (or  equivalent),  policies,  and  procedures  for  new 
multisector regulator. 
 
5.  Output 2: Enhanced sector planning capacity at relevant government department. 
Consultants  will  deliver  detailed  recommendations for  establishing  the  policy  framework to 
identify, prioritize, select, and implement discrete renewable generation and service expansion 
investments.  Key  outputs  will  include:  (i)  development  of  capacity  within  the  relevant 
government department to identify and prioritize public or private investments in the electricity 
sector; (ii) procedures for sanctioning publicly financed and private sector investments, including 
tendering and authorization procedures, and policies and procedures for treatment of unsolicited 
investment  proposals;  and  (iii)  prefeasibility  studies  for  one  generation  and  one  network 
(transmission or distribution) project suitable for public investment or competitive tendering for 
private sector development. Prefeasibility studies will be prepared in accordance with ADB 
guidelines for technical, economic, and financial feasibility; and guidelines for environmental and 
social  safeguards,  with  corresponding  reporting  and  documentation,  and  establishment  of 
capacity  within  relevant  government  departments  to  prepare  such  documentation  for 
subsequent candidate projects and monitoring of compliance with safeguards covenants. 
 
6.  An  indicative  personnel,  skills,  and  task  assignment  schedule  is  presented  below.  
Consultants are expected to propose their own personnel schedule and level of effort for key 
experts to achieve the stated objectives. 
 
7.  Electrical engineer (transmission and distribution) and team leader (international,  
4 person-months, intermittent). The expert will carry out these tasks: 
(i)  serve as team leader and take overall responsibility for delivery of outputs of this 
component of the TA; 
(ii)  schedule  and  manage  work  of  experts  in  his  team  in  coordination  with 
government counterparts; 
(iii)  in  cooperation  with  other  team  experts,  develop  screening  criteria  for 
prioritization of generation and network expansion investments; 
(iv)  apply screening criteria to prospective investments and select one network and 
one  generation  candidate  project  for  preliminary  design  and  feasibility 
assessment; and 
(v)  present results of prioritization findings and feasibility assessments of selected 
investment projects. 
 
8.  Geographic information systems expert (international, 2 person-months, intermittent). 
The expert will carry out these tasks:

Appendix 3  11 
 
 
(i)  collect and analyze relevant data from available sources, including FEA and 
other government and nongovernment sources; 
(ii)  assess data quality and adequacy; and 
(iii)  present  visual  representation  of  existing  networks  and  served  and  unserved 
populations,  detailing  population  densities,  topographic  and  other  prominent 
features, and land tenure and use (the scope of the representations should cover 
all Fiji islands with full-time populations greater than 100 persons). 
 
9.  Renewable energy generation expert(s) (international, 4 person-months, intermittent). 
The expert will carry out these tasks: 
(i)  develop  screening  criteria  and  methodology  for  identification  of  generation 
options for incremental system load to expand service to new customers; and 
(ii)  prepare  preliminary  design  specifications  and  cost  estimates  for  preliminary 
feasibility studies and project investment memoranda for one to three projects 
identified using the integrated project screening criteria. 
 
10.  Legal and regulatory expert (international, 3 person-months, intermittent). The expert 
will carry out these tasks: 
(i)  review  licensing  regime  for  third  party  (i.e.,  non-FEA)  operators  to  establish 
isolated generation, supply, and distribution services; 
(ii)  review interconnection (grid code) and market access arrangements for third 
party operators to use FEA network capacities to sell power generated to FEA or 
third parties, or to take delivery of power generated by FEA or other third parties; 
(iii)  review license obligations of FEA and potential new market entrants relating to 
universal service obligations in defined service areas, as may exist; 
(iv)  propose revisions to licensing, grid code and/or market access, and universal 
service  obligations  regimes  to  facilitate  new  market  entrants’  investments  in 
generation, supply, and distribution; 
(v)  review  public  tendering  regime  for  power  projects  of  the  type  selected  for 
preliminary feasibility assessment under proposed screening methodology; and 
(vi)  support the private sector investment and transaction advisor in preparing project 
information memoranda for selected investment opportunities. 
 
11.  Project finance expert and economist (international, 3 person-months, intermittent). 
The expert will perform these tasks: 
(i)  contribute financial and economic assessment criteria to screening criteria for 
identification and prioritization of generation and network expansion investment 
projects; 
(ii)  prepare financial and economic feasibility assessments of candidate investment 
projects identified through the application of said screening criteria; and 
(iii)  develop  indicative  financing  arrangements  for  inclusion  in  information 
memoranda of candidate private sector investment projects. 
 
12.  Private sector investment and transaction advisor (international, 4 person-months, 
intermittent). The expert will execute these tasks: 
(i)  confirm  candidate  private  sector  transaction  projects  from  among  prioritized 
projects identified through application of developed screening criteria, 
(ii)  prepare model information memoranda of confirmed candidate projects, 
(iii)  prepare candidate project term sheets, and 
(iv)  develop tendering procedures for private sector investment in candidate projects.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
13.  Environmental safeguards specialist (international, 2 person-months). The specialist 
will conduct these tasks: 
(i)  prepare environmental assessments for the two candidate investment projects 
and assist counterpart staff in documenting procedures; 
(ii)  provide  inputs  into  the  assessments  from  an  environmental  safeguards  and 
climate change adaptation perspective as agreed with the team leader; 
(iii)  prepare  an  environmental  assessment  and  review  framework  for  candidate 
projects, including need to identify climate change risks and incorporation of 
adaptation and/or resilience requirements into investment screening and design; 
(iv)  screen proposed investments for their environmental impacts and determine their 
categories of impacts following ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009);  
(v)  prepare  an  initial  environmental  examination  or  environmental  impact 
assessment (including environmental management plan), using ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy Statement  and Fiji environmental law for the investment projects; 
(vi)  assist relevant government departments in conducting community consultations 
regarding potential environmental impacts of investments in coordination with the 
requirements for social safeguards and established processes currently practiced 
within FEA and relevant government agencies;  
(vii)  identify relevant government departments’ capacity to ensure compliance with 
environmental  safeguards  requirements  and  identify  training  and  capacity 
building needs; 
(viii)  establish a grievance redress mechanism to be adopted by relevant government 
departments in coordination with the social safeguard specialists;  
(ix)  assist  relevant  government  departments  in  disclosure  of  the  environmental 
assessment  and  review  framework  and  core  subproject(s)  environmental 
assessment(s)  according  to  ADB’s  Public  Communications  Policy  2011  and 
government’s environmental law and regulations requirements; and 
(x)  provide relevant safeguard inputs during preparation and processing of the two 
candidate investment projects. 
   
14.  Social and poverty expert (international, 2 person-months). The expert will perform 
these tasks: 
(i)  assess  impacts  of  land  acquisition,  involuntary  resettlement,  and  indigenous 
peoples;  
(ii)  prepare  resettlement  framework  and/or  resettlement  plan,  and  indigenous 
peoples’ framework and/or indigenous peoples plan (IPP) as required for the 
candidate investment projects;  
(iii)  assist  counterpart  staff  in  conducting  public  consultations  and  information 
disclosure on safeguards and documenting procedures; and  
(iv)  undertake poverty, social, and gender analyses for proposed investment projects 
according and prepare necessary documents for the proposed projects. 
 
a.   On involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. The expert will perform 
these tasks: 
(i)   screen  investments  for  impacts  on  involuntary  resettlement  and 
indigenous peoples, and determine categories of impacts according to 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement; 
(ii)  assess impacts on involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples and 
prepare the resettlement plan and IPP for proposed investment projects in 
accordance with ADB Safeguard Policy Statement. For the preparation of 
the resettlement plan, carry out a census of affected persons, detailed

Appendix 3  13 
 
 
inventory of losses, and replacement cost survey of affected land assets 
in  coordination  with  relevant  land  administration  authorities.  If  a 
resettlement plan or IPP are not required, prepare due diligence reports 
confirming this; 
(iii)  prepare resettlement framework and indigenous peoples framework if the 
project is developed as a sector project as required; 
(iv)   review  country  systems  (laws,  institutions,  etc.)  on  involuntary 
resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples,  comparing  them  with  ADB 
Safeguard Policy Statement principles, and include gap-filling measures 
in relevant frameworks and plans; 
(v)  prepare stakeholder consultation and communication plan — consult with 
affected  persons,  communities,  and  other  stakeholders,  and  assist 
government  departments  in  disclosure  of  information,  including  draft 
safeguard documents; 
(vi)  prepare documentation of consultations and disclosures; 
(vii)  assess  government’s  capacity  for  compliance  with  ADB  safeguards 
monitoring requirements; 
(viii)  provide  training  and  seminars  to  relevant  government  agencies  on 
safeguards compliance and monitoring; and 
(ix)  provide  safeguard  inputs  during  preparation  of  candidate  investment 
projects.   
 
b.   On social, poverty, and gender aspects. The expert will perform these tasks: 
 
(i)  prepare  a  poverty  and  social  assessment  (PSA)  report    for  the  two 
candidate projects, as well as field studies and community consultations, 
including: 
(a) baseline socioeconomic profiles of the proposed project areas, especially 
in relation to access to modern energy services; 
(b) assessment  of  impact of  existing  energy  service  access  on  essential 
social  services  (e.g.,  schools  and  health  facilities),  including  gender 
dimensions;   
(c)  expected  social,  economic,  and  gender  benefits  of  the  candidate 
investment projects and identification of primary beneficiaries; and 
(d) potential  negative  impacts  resulting  from  the  investment  projects  and 
proposed mitigation measures. 
(ii)  assist in identifying and preparing project designs and implementation 
plans for the investment project that are pro-poor, socially inclusive, and 
gender-mainstreamed, along with those to minimize potentially negative 
social impacts, using results from the PSA; 
(iii)  prepare required documents for the candidate investment projects, such 
as summary poverty reduction and social strategy, gender action plan), 
and other inputs, based on PSA findings and other relevant analyses;   
(iv)  Prepare the gender action plan according to ADB Guidelines for Gender 
Mainstreaming Categories by including: 
(a) gender-responsive  designs  that  address  women’s  specific  needs  for 
access to electricity, 
(b) concrete plans to ensure women’s participation in all project activities 
during project implementation stage, and 
(c) specific targets and indicators to monitor project benefits to women and 
mitigate any adverse impacts.
